dt: {bc}to cause the infliction of (vengeance or punishment)
{bc}to give free play or course to (malevolent feeling)

et: Middle English {it}wreken{/it} "to drive out, avenge, vent, express (anger, etc.)," going back to Old English {it}wrecan{/it} "to press forward, drive out, banish, avenge, punish," going back to Germanic {it}*wrekan-{/it} "to drive out, pursue" (whence Old Saxon {it}wrekan{/it} "to avenge," Old High German {it}rehhan,{/it} Old Norse {it}reka{/it} "to drive, thrust, take vengeance," Gothic {it}wrikan{/it} "to persecute"), of uncertain origin

Placed by some under Indo-European {it}*u̯reg-{/it} "follow a track" (whence, allegedly, Sanskrit {it}vrajant-{/it} "wandering," Latin {it}urgēre{/it} "to press, weigh down"), though the semantic relations between compared forms are not close.
shortdef: to cause the infliction of (vengeance or punishment)

dt.t: A powerful tornado {it}wreaked havoc{/it} on the small village.
The virus {it}wreaked havoc{/it} on my computer.
